title: How to Make Pull Apart Garlic Bread

methods.name: Making Pull Apart Garlic Bread From Scratch

steps.headline: Combine the water, sugar, and yeast.
steps.description: Pour 1/2 cup (120 ml) of warm water into a large mixing bowl or one that will fit in a stand mixer. Sprinkle 1 teaspoon of active dry yeast and 1 tablespoon of white sugar over the water. Set the mixture aside for 5 to 10 minutes. You don't need to stir it yet. The yeast, water, and sugar will look cloudy and foamy after it's rested.

steps.headline: Mix in the butter, milk, salt, and flour.
steps.description: Use a dough hook attachment or strong beaters to stir in 1 tablespoon of softened unsalted butter, 1/2 cup (120 ml) of milk, and 1 heaping teaspoon of salt. Keep the mixer on low speed and slowly mix in 3 cups (380 g) of bread flour. Keep kneading and mixing the dough for 7 to 10 minutes. The dough will begin to stick to the bottom of the bowl as it forms a sticky ball.

steps.headline: Combine the herbed garlic butter.
steps.description: Melt 4 tablespoons (55 g) of butter in a small bowl and stir in 1 pinch of salt, a handful of finely chopped parsley leaves, and 2 cloves of finely minced garlic. This will be the mixture you dip the bread into. Taste the herbed garlic butter and add more salt, garlic, or parsley according to your liking.

steps.headline: Divide the dough into pieces and dip them in the butter.
steps.description: Scoop the dough out of the mixing bowl and cut it into two portions. Take one portion of dough and cut the dough into round, bite-sized pieces. Dip the pieces in the herbed garlic butter and fill one 5.75x3-inch (14.6x7.6 cm) loaf pan. Repeat this with the other portion of dough and fill another small loaf pan. If you have leftover herbed garlic butter, set it aside to brush over the baked bread.

steps.headline: Let the loaves prove and preheat the oven.
steps.description: Cover each of the pans of dough with plastic wrap and put them in a warm place. Let them rise until they've doubled in volume. This should take about an hour. and let rise until doubled, about 1 hour. Turn on the oven to 350 degrees F (175 C). If you want to prove the dough in the oven with the oven light on, just remove them after 45 minutes so you can preheat the oven.

steps.headline: Bake the pull apart garlic bread.
steps.description: Remove the plastic wrap from the loaves and place the loaves in the preheated oven. Bake the bread for 30 minutes. The pull apart bread should turn a dark golden brown once it's finished baking. Brush the leftover herbed garlic butter over the bread before you serve it. Be careful when tipping the bread out of the loaf tins, if you've just brushed hot butter over the loaves.

methods.name: Making Pull Apart Garlic Bread From a Purchased Loaf

steps.headline: Slice the bread and preheat the oven.
steps.description: Turn the oven on to 350 degrees F (175 C). Get out one 16 to 20-ounce (500 to 550 g) round loaf of artisan bread and use a bread knife to carefully slice the bread into rows that are about 1-inch (2.5 cm) wide. Turn the bread 90 degrees and cut rows across the bread. Avoid cutting all the way down and through the bread. Cutting rows that cross will make a grid-like pattern across the bread. This will make it easy to pull apart after it's baked.

steps.headline: Combine the cheese and garlic.
steps.description: Place 1 1/2 to 2 cups (6 to 8 ounces or 170 to 226 g) of shredded cheese (like Monterey Jack, mozzarella, provolone, cheddar, or a mix) into a small bowl and stir in 2 cloves of finely minced garlic. You should also melt 1/4 cup (25 g) of unsalted butter and set it aside. If you'd like, you can also cook and crumble up bacon or sausage. Stir this into the cheese and garlic.

steps.headline: Stuff the bread.
steps.description: Gently move the rows of bread apart and fill the gaps with the cheese and garlic. To make things easier, start by filling all of the rows extending from you. Then turn the bread 90 degrees and fill in all of the rows that now extend from you. You might want to ask someone to help you hold the rows of bread apart as you stuff the bread.

steps.headline: Pour butter over the bread and wrap it.
steps.description: Place the stuffed bread on a large sheet of aluminum foil. Pour the melted butter over the top of the stuffed bread and wrap the foil up and over the bread. Seal the aluminum foil shut so the loaf is tightly wrapped. Covering the bread with foil will help the cheese melt and will prevent the bread from drying out as it bakes.

steps.headline: Bake the pull apart garlic bread.
steps.description: Put the bread in the preheated oven and bake it for 20 minutes. Carefully remove it from the oven and open the top of the foil. Return the bread to the oven for 10 more minutes. This will make the top of the bread crisp up and ensure that the cheese is bubbly. Remove the bread from the oven and serve it once it's cool enough to tear into. Consider sprinkling minced parsley or chives over the top for a bright garnish.

Sprinkle 1 teaspoon of active dry yeast and 1 tablespoon of white sugar over the water. Set the mixture aside for 5 to 10 minutes. You don't need to stir it yet. The yeast, water, and sugar will look cloudy and foamy after it's rested. Mix in the butter, milk, salt, and flour. Use a dough hook attachment or strong beaters to stir in 1 tablespoon of softened unsalted butter, 1/2 cup (120 ml) of milk, and 1 heaping teaspoon of salt. Keep the mixer on low speed and slowly mix in 3 cups (380 g) of bread flour. Keep kneading and mixing the dough for 7 to 10 minutes. The dough will begin to stick to the bottom of the bowl as it forms a sticky ball. Combine the herbed garlic butter. Melt 4 tablespoons (55 g) of butter in a small bowl and stir in 1 pinch of salt, a handful of finely chopped parsley leaves, and 2 cloves of finely minced garlic. This will be the mixture you dip the bread into. Taste the herbed garlic butter and add more salt, garlic, or parsley according to your liking. Divide the dough into pieces and dip them in the butter. Scoop the dough out of the mixing bowl and cut it into two portions. Take one portion of dough and cut the dough into round, bite-sized pieces. Dip the pieces in the herbed garlic butter and fill one 5.75x3-inch (14.6x7.6 cm) loaf pan. Repeat this with the other portion of dough and fill another small loaf pan. If you have leftover herbed garlic butter, set it aside to brush over the baked bread. Let the loaves prove and preheat the oven. Cover each of the pans of dough with plastic wrap and put them in a warm place. Let them rise until they've doubled in volume. This should take about an hour. and let rise until doubled, about 1 hour. Turn on the oven to 350 degrees F (175 C). If you want to prove the dough in the oven with the oven light on, just remove them after 45 minutes so you can preheat the oven. Bake the pull apart garlic bread. Remove the plastic wrap from the loaves and place the loaves in the preheated oven. Bake the bread for 30 minutes. The pull apart bread should turn a dark golden brown once it's finished baking. Brush the leftover herbed garlic butter over the bread before you serve it. Be careful when tipping the bread out of the loaf tins, if you've just brushed hot butter over the loaves. Making Pull Apart Garlic Bread From a Purchased Loaf Slice the bread and preheat the oven. Turn the oven on to 350 degrees F (175 C). Get out one 16 to 20-ounce (500 to 550 g) round loaf of artisan bread and use a bread knife to carefully slice the bread into rows that are about 1-inch (2.5 cm) wide. Turn the bread 90 degrees and cut rows across the bread. Avoid cutting all the way down and through the bread. Cutting rows that cross will make a grid-like pattern across the bread. This will make it easy to pull apart after it's baked. Combine the cheese and garlic. Place 1 1/2 to 2 cups (6 to 8 ounces or 170 to 226 g) of shredded cheese (like Monterey Jack, mozzarella, provolone, cheddar, or a mix) into a small bowl and stir in 2 cloves of finely minced garlic. You should also melt 1/4 cup (25 g) of unsalted butter and set it aside. If you'd like, you can also cook and crumble up bacon or sausage. Stir this into the cheese and garlic. Stuff the bread. Gently move the rows of bread apart and fill the gaps with the cheese and garlic. To make things easier, start by filling all of the rows extending from you. Then turn the bread 90 degrees and fill in all of the rows that now extend from you. You might want to ask someone to help you hold the rows of bread apart as you stuff the bread. Pour butter over the bread and wrap it. Place the stuffed bread on a large sheet of aluminum foil. Pour the melted butter over the top of the stuffed bread and wrap the foil up and over the bread. Seal the aluminum foil shut so the loaf is tightly wrapped. Covering the bread with foil will help the cheese melt and will prevent the bread from drying out as it bakes. Bake the pull apart garlic bread. Put the bread in the preheated oven and bake it for 20 minutes. Carefully remove it from the oven and open the top of the foil. Return the bread to the oven for 10 more minutes. This will make the top of the bread crisp up and ensure that the cheese is bubbly. Remove the bread from the oven and serve it once it's cool enough to tear into. Consider sprinkling minced parsley or chives over the top for a bright garnish.

Pour 1/2 cup (120 ml) of warm water into a large mixing bowl or one that will fit in a stand mixer.
Sprinkle 1 teaspoon of active dry yeast and 1 tablespoon of white sugar over the water.
Set the mixture aside for 5 to 10 minutes.
You don't need to stir it yet.
The yeast, water, and sugar will look cloudy and foamy after it's rested.
Mix in the butter, milk, salt, and flour.
Use a dough hook attachment or strong beaters to stir in 1 tablespoon of softened unsalted butter, 1/2 cup (120 ml) of milk, and 1 heaping teaspoon of salt.
Keep the mixer on low speed and slowly mix in 3 cups (380 g) of bread flour.
Keep kneading and mixing the dough for 7 to 10 minutes.
The dough will begin to stick to the bottom of the bowl as it forms a sticky ball.
Combine the herbed garlic butter.
Melt 4 tablespoons (55 g) of butter in a small bowl and stir in 1 pinch of salt, a handful of finely chopped parsley leaves, and 2 cloves of finely minced garlic.
This will be the mixture you dip the bread into.
Taste the herbed garlic butter and add more salt, garlic, or parsley according to your liking.

Take one portion of dough and cut the dough into round, bite-sized pieces.
Dip the pieces in the herbed garlic butter and fill one 5.75x3-inch (14.6x7.6 cm) loaf pan.

If you have leftover herbed garlic butter, set it aside to brush over the baked bread.

Remove the plastic wrap from the loaves and place the loaves in the preheated oven.

Making Pull Apart Garlic Bread From a Purchased Loaf Slice the bread and preheat the oven.
Turn the oven on to 350 degrees F (175 C).
Get out one 16 to 20-ounce (500 to 550 g) round loaf of artisan bread and use a bread knife to carefully slice the bread into rows that are about 1-inch (2.5 cm) wide.
Turn the bread 90 degrees and cut rows across the bread.
Avoid cutting all the way down and through the bread.
Cutting rows that cross will make a grid-like pattern across the bread.
This will make it easy to pull apart after it's baked.
Combine the cheese and garlic.
Place 1 1/2 to 2 cups (6 to 8 ounces or 170 to 226 g) of shredded cheese (like Monterey Jack, mozzarella, provolone, cheddar, or a mix) into a small bowl and stir in 2 cloves of finely minced garlic.
You should also melt 1/4 cup (25 g) of unsalted butter and set it aside.
If you'd like, you can also cook and crumble up bacon or sausage.
Stir this into the cheese and garlic.
Stuff the bread.
Gently move the rows of bread apart and fill the gaps with the cheese and garlic.
To make things easier, start by filling all of the rows extending from you.
Then turn the bread 90 degrees and fill in all of the rows that now extend from you.
You might want to ask someone to help you hold the rows of bread apart as you stuff the bread.
Pour butter over the bread and wrap it.
Place the stuffed bread on a large sheet of aluminum foil.
Pour the melted butter over the top of the stuffed bread and wrap the foil up and over the bread.
Seal the aluminum foil shut so the loaf is tightly wrapped.
Covering the bread with foil will help the cheese melt and will prevent the bread from drying out as it bakes.
Bake the pull apart garlic bread.
Put the bread in the preheated oven and bake it for 20 minutes.
Carefully remove it from the oven and open the top of the foil.
Return the bread to the oven for 10 more minutes.
This will make the top of the bread crisp up and ensure that the cheese is bubbly.
Remove the bread from the oven and serve it once it's cool enough to tear into.
Consider sprinkling minced parsley or chives over the top for a bright garnish.
